sub_title: Strategic Communicator and Facilitator | Interdisciplinary Researcher and Educator | Global Project Manager | Media Specialist
summary:
As a transnational and multidisciplinary educator, researcher, and story-teller, I am passionate about facilitating community-centered approaches that address complex social issues. I currently work to promote equitable and transformational organizational development at Greenpeace International by creating structures for healthy collaboration and communication between diverse global stakeholders. 

My work has taken me to the United States, Taiwan, and the Netherlands, and focuses on cultivating sustainable communities and systems that promote self-empowerment, continuous education, and change advocacy. Facilitation and communication are key to change—I collaborate with small local teams and large international organizations to generate intersectoral participatory solutions that address global and local social issues including global/local health inequalities, international migration, racial injustice, and climate justice.

awards.title: Amy Ling Yellow Light Award for Integrity
Social Justice & Advocacy Award
awards.description: Awarded for organizational contributions during APIDA Heritage Month

profile_positions.description: Coordinated an organization-wide engagement plan to design a three year strategic plan using stakeholder collaboration, virtual retreat facilitation, and qualitative analysis. Also facilitated monthly staff meetings and co-wrote the vision statement for the organizational Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion, and Safety strategy.
profile_positions.title: Internal Communications and Engagement Specialist

profile_positions.description: I currently manage the distribution process of a €4 million Digital Transformation Fund to 25 National/Regional offices. I also led and designed the creation of an Justice, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion, and Safety educational track for Greenpeace's Technology Camp. In addition, I also represented 300+ staff as a member of the International Executive Director Recruitment Committee to ensure staff interests were incorporated into a new job description and interview process.
profile_positions.title: Interim Project Manager

company.name: Taiwan International Workers’ Association (台灣國際勞動協會）

profile_positions.company: Taiwan International Workers’ Association (台灣國際勞動協會）
profile_positions.description: As part of my public health research, I worked as a research and communications assistant at a migrant worker community advocacy NGO called Taiwan International Workers Association. At TIWA, I helped to develop and coordinate events designed for educating and engaging international audiences about migrant worker issues in Taiwan. I also used Participatory Action Research and design thinking to collaborate with migrant workers to identify health issues and design multilingual policy explainers regarding labor policy reform. I’ve also had the privilege of using my Mandarin and Education skills to conduct weekly Mandarin Chinese lessons to 20-40 migrant workers from different cultural backgrounds and varying levels of English and Chinese, and to serve as a translator in both medical and group dialogue settings. Working at TIWA has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my life—I’ve forged strong relationships and have learned important new perspectives about international organizing and change-making.
profile_positions.title: Research and Project Assistant/Communications Specialist

company.name: (Fulbright Taiwan) Fulbright Foundation For Scholarly Exchange

profile_positions.description:
I utilized a combination of Participatory Action Research and ethnographic methods to explore how labor, immigration, and healthcare policy affects the public health outcomes of domestic migrant caregivers in Taiwan. For my research, I explored how various transnational factors lead to the structural marginalization and invisibilization of domestic migrant caregivers, and the variation of negative health effects that are produced as a result. I’ve had the privilege of doing my fieldwork at Taiwan International Workers’ Association, where I’ve forged strong relationships with both migrant workers and local activists and organizers. 

Fulbright Fellowship pursuing a degree in Global Health a National Taiwan University
profile_positions.title: Fulbright Fellow

profile_positions.description:
When I was 16 years-old, I started my own photography business in which I developed key management skills and community entrepreneurship skills. In my 7 years of experience, I’ve photographed over 150 portrait sessions, 15 weddings, and 20+ stylized commercial and lifestyle shoots. I pride myself in my participatory creative process—I coordinated with clients from every stage of the creative process, from conceptualizing the project, empowering them to feel comfortable and confident during the shoot, the editing process, and delivery of the final product. I also managed the logistic communications, including scheduling consultations, photoshoot details, invoices, deposit/payment status, contract completion, and other relevant details.
 While I started my photography business in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, I’ve have had the privilege to work on projects in Los Angeles, Chicago, and even Taiwan. I’m grateful that I’ve been able to apply these creative story-telling skills in other aspects of my work and research as well.
profile_positions.title: Professional Photographer

company.name: University of Wisconsin-Madison Office of Student Affairs

profile_positions.description:
After a year of organizing a cross-cultural community campaign for more institutional support for students of color at UW, the administration agreed to our demands and hired me to help create the first Asian Pacific Islander Desi American (APIDA) Student Center. In this position, I helped manage the transition and integration of our informal student-led grassroots campaign into an institutional organization in a way that protected community power and engagement within the new structure, including creating community advisory boards, student committees, and community engagement events. 
I also maintained strong relationships with the student and local community to ensure accurate representation in program design, meetings with the Board, and press releases.
I also established a culture of sustainability in APIDA-related labor and activism by recruiting leaders from diverse affinity group organizations to coordinate and participate in APIDA programming, social justice education, and community advocacy events. This included working with the campus community to plan the first official APIDA Heritage Month: I chaired a committee that worked together to design, advertise, and implement a month’s worth of community cultural programming for the APIDA campus community. During this process, I created and maintained a database of organizational information of different community stakeholders on campus, including diverse affinity group organization leaders, community organizations, national institutions, alumni, donors, and media.
profile_positions.title: Asian Pacific Islander Desi American (APIDA) Campus Community Organizer

profile_positions.company: Institute for Research on Poverty, University of Wisconsin-Madison
profile_positions.description:
The Institute for Research on Poverty (IRP) is a nonpartisan research institution dedicated to producing and disseminating rigorous evidence to inform policies and programs to combat poverty, inequality, and their effects in the United States. In my position, I updated design language of the Institute’s research publications and graphics to industry standards, resulting in increased engagement with internal and external audiences. I also collaborated with editing team to simplify research language and writing process for policy makers and politicians. This enabled us to interpreted data and concepts to create easy-to-understand graphics that effectively communicated complex information to lay audiences.
In addition, I worked with a team of graduate students to conduct a total of 150 qualitative interviews with local residents for part of the Dream-up project, a project designed to work with the local community to increase the income of lower and middle socio-economic-status families.
profile_positions.title: Communication and Design Intern

profile_positions.description: I worked with a team of dedicated RAs to create an inclusive community focused on education and equity.
profile_positions.title: Resident Assistant
